data.title: Tutorial: Mounting Databases
data.description:
Hello Agent, before heading down to earth, lets first learn how to use the SQL systems. Databases are organized collections of structured information or data that can be easily accessed, managed, and updated.

To use a database, first we need to mount it.

  1. Click the DB REGISTRY button at the top of the screen
  2. In the registry, find and click the MOUNT button next to the mission_control database
  3. Close the DB Registry panel by clicking the âœ•

This will mount the missions database so you can access it. Once mounted, you'll be able to complete this mission and proceed to the next where we'll learn how to run SQL queries.
If you ever get stuck press hint for a tiny but of help or solution for the answer; currently there are no penalties, so just have fun.
data.hint: Click the DB REGISTRY button, find mission_control, click MOUNT, then close the registry panel.
data.solution: Click the DB REGISTRY button, find mission_control, click MOUNT, then close the registry panel.
data.successMessage: Excellent! You've mounted your first database. Now you can access the mission_control database to see what we have available. Click the green button below to continue on.

data.title: Tutorial: First Query
data.description:
Now that you've mounted the mission_control database, let's run your first SQL query.

The SQL Console: This is where you'll write and execute SQL queries Try running your first query: SELECT * FROM missions; SQL Explanation:
  • SELECT * - Retrieves all columns from the table (the asterisk is a wildcard meaning "select everything")
  • FROM missions - Specifies which table to get data from
  • ; - Marks the end of the SQL statement
This will show you all the available missions in the database. The results will appear in the Results Area below.
data.hint: Type SELECT * FROM missions; in the SQL console and click Execute to see all the missions.
data.successMessage: Great job! You've run your first SQL query and can now see all available missions in the database.

data.title: Tutorial: Explore Planets
data.description: Now let's explore some planetary data. First, we need to mount another database. 1. Click the DB REGISTRY button at the top 2. Find the galaxy1 database and click MOUNT 3. Close the DB Registry panel 4. Try running: SELECT * FROM planets; This will show information about all planets in our database.
data.hint: First mount the galaxy1 database, then run SELECT * FROM planets; to see information about all planets.
data.successMessage: Excellent! You've mounted the galaxy1 database and retrieved data from the planets table.

data.title: Tutorial: Interactive Map
data.description: Great job running your first query! Now let's explore the interactive map feature. Our database contains planetary data, but we need geographical information to use the map. 1. First, click the DB REGISTRY button at the top 2. Find the maps database and click MOUNT 3. Close the DB Registry panel 4. Try running: SELECT earth FROM maps; This will open our interactive map interface.
data.hint: The command SELECT earth FROM maps; will open the map. Make sure the 'maps' database is mounted first.
data.successMessage: You've successfully opened the interactive map! This will be crucial for finding and activating missions.

data.title: Tutorial: Mission Database
data.description: Now that you can access the map, let's load our mission database to see available missions. 1. Click the DB REGISTRY button again 2. Find and mount the mission_control database 3. Close the DB Registry and run: SELECT * FROM missions; This will show all available missions. You can click on any mission row to load it.
data.hint: First mount the 'mission_control' database, then run SELECT * FROM missions; to see all available missions.
data.successMessage: Perfect! Now you can see and select from all available missions in the system.

data.title: Mission: First Contact
data.description: The Galactic Council needs information about the planets in the Proxima system. Objective: Retrieve a list of all planets, ordered by their distance from the sun.
data.hint:
Use SELECT to retrieve data, and ORDER BY to arrange the results.
Example: SELECT * FROM table_name ORDER BY column_name;
data.successMessage: Excellent work, SQL Knight! You've successfully retrieved the planetary data for the Galactic Council.

mapDetails.description: First Contact mission in New York

data.title: Mission: Resource Discovery
data.description: The Galactic Trading Federation needs to know which resources are most valuable for interstellar commerce. Objective: Find all resources with a market value greater than 5000, ordered by value (highest first).
data.hint:
Use WHERE to filter results and ORDER BY with DESC to sort in descending order.
Example: SELECT * FROM table_name WHERE column_name > value ORDER BY column_name DESC;
data.successMessage: Outstanding work! The Galactic Trading Federation can now prioritize the most valuable resources for their commercial routes.

data.title: Mission: Population Census
data.description: The Interstellar Health Organization needs to identify which alien species have the largest populations to prioritize medical aid. Objective: Find all species with a population greater than 3 million, ordered by intelligence level.
data.hint:
Combine WHERE and ORDER BY to filter and sort the results.
Example: SELECT * FROM table_name WHERE column_name > value ORDER BY other_column;
data.successMessage: Well done! The Interstellar Health Organization can now allocate medical resources effectively based on population and intelligence levels.

data.title: Paris With Love
data.description: A rare Parisian artifact has been discovered containing information about ancient sustainability practices. Objective: Query the artifact database to find sustainability techniques ordered by efficiency rating.
data.hint:
This is a basic query. Use SELECT and ORDER BY to get the sustainability techniques ordered properly.
Example: SELECT * FROM techniques ORDER BY efficiency_rating DESC;
data.successMessage: Magnifique! You've unlocked ancient sustainability knowledge that will help modern Paris become more eco-friendly.

data.title: Mission: Planetary Relations
data.description: Scientists need to understand the relationship between planets and their native species. Objective: Find all planets and their corresponding species, including planets without any species.
data.hint:
Use JOIN operations to combine data from multiple tables.
Example: SELECT * FROM table1 LEFT JOIN table2 ON table1.id = table2.foreign_id;
data.successMessage: Excellent analysis! The scientists now have a complete picture of planetary habitation patterns.

data.title: Mission: Resource Analysis
data.description: The Galactic Trading Federation needs a summary of resource value by planet. Objective: Calculate the total market value of resources for each planet and order by total value (highest first).
data.hint:
Use GROUP BY with aggregate functions to summarize data.
Example: SELECT column1, SUM(column2) FROM table GROUP BY column1;
data.successMessage: Outstanding work! The Federation now has clear insight into the resource value distribution across planets.

mapDetails.description: Resource Analysis mission in Rio de Janeiro
